entry.title: How Talent Intelligence Hub Connects 8 SuccessFactors Capabilities
entry.content:
Hi Readers,

When most HR professionals hear "Talent Intelligence Hub," they immediately think Growth Portfolio and career development. While that's certainly TIH's crown jewel, but limiting your perspective to just career pathing is like using a smartphone only for making calls. You're missing most of its potential.

TIH is far more than a career development tool – it's the intelligent backbone that transforms your entire SuccessFactors ecosystem.

While Growth Portfolio showcases TIH's career pathing capabilities, the real magic happens when TIH integrates seamlessly with Performance Management, Recruiting, Learning, Employee Central, and Compensation. These integrations turn isolated HR processes into an intelligent, connected talent ecosystem where every module becomes smarter through shared skill intelligence.

Think of TIH not as another module, but as your talent data command center where skills, capabilities, and career insights flow across every touchpoint of the employee journey. When properly integrated, TIH transforms reactive HR processes into predictive, personalized talent experiences that drive real business outcomes.

Let’s explore how Talent Intelligence Hub interacts with major modules in SuccessFactors and transforms key people processes.

1. Performance Management and 360 Reviews

TIH supercharges performance processes by letting managers and peers rate skills directly in Performance forms and 360 Reviews. 

  • Average ratings in 360 Reviews dynamically update the proficiency level for each skill in an employee’s growth portfolio.
  • Skill and competency ratings feed directly into the growth portfolio, building a rich, evolving view of employee capabilities.

2. Career Development

Career growth becomes more strategic with TIH:

  • The Career Worksheet identifies readiness for future roles, pulling proficiency data from the Growth Portfolio.

  • Employees and managers can associate specific skills with development goals, ensuring development plans are tailored and actionable.

3. Succession Management

Building future-ready teams is easier:

  • Talent Search for successors includes powerful filters based on skills, competencies, and ratings from the Growth Portfolio.
  • This ensures succession decisions are grounded in real, validated capability data.

4. Continuous Performance Management

TIH leverages Continuous Performance Management (CPM) to infer skills and recommend development actions:

  • CPM recommendations, powered by AI, are automatically sourced into the employee’s growth portfolio.
  • This turns everyday feedback and activities into actionable talent insights.

5. Dynamic Teams

Organizations now form agile, project-based teams with confidence:

  • Dynamic team roles include descriptions and proficiencies needed — skills are rated and tracked per assignment.
  • Once assignments are completed, new skills and experiences are added to employee growth portfolios, ensuring continuous skill evolution.

6. Opportunity Marketplace

SAP’s Opportunity Marketplace connects gigs, projects, and stretch assignments with employee skills:

  • TIH powers assignment recommendations based on growth portfolio attributes.
  • Skill-based filtering makes matches relevant and useful.

7. People Analytics

TIH enriches analytics, giving managers and admins deep visibility:

  • Dashboards highlight attributes of direct reports, average proficiency levels, rating gaps, and more.
  • This enables targeted investment in learning and succession.

8. Recruiting

Even the hiring process benefits:

  • Candidate skills can be rated and commented on by interviewers, feeding into the TIH for future growth and suitability analysis.

 In Interview Central, competencies, skills and interview questions from the job requisition are pulled.

9. Learning

TIH is the bridge between learning and performance:

  • After course completion, skill proficiency ratings update automatically in the Growth Portfolio.
  • Employees can search for learning content by skill, and receive personalized recommendations shaped by their portfolios.

Organizations embracing TIH are positioned to develop agile, future-ready teams and empower employees on their career journeys. If you’re looking to maximize your SuccessFactors investment, integrating with the Talent Intelligence Hub is the smart next step!

If you're planning a TIH implementation, currently in the middle of one, or just trying to understand what this platform does beyond the marketing materials, my blog will help cut through the noise and focus on what really matters for a successful deployment.  The stuff that matters when you're in the middle of an implementation and need straight answers. I've consolidated the key learnings from multiple projects to give you the facts without the fluff, based on what I've seen work and what doesn't in practice. TIH - Key Learnings from Client Projects 

Thank you for taking the time to read.

You are welcome to express your views and ask any queries in the comment section of this blog. I would be pleased to impart my knowledge to you.  Share this blog with your colleagues.

Thank you!!

entry.title: Re: Asset depreciation adjustment based on APC
entry.content:
Great question 👍

Yes — in SAP Asset Accounting (FI-AA) you can maintain time-dependent useful life in the asset master, but you need to be aware of how SAP treats it:

🔹 1. Time-Dependent Data in Asset Master

 In AS02 → Time-Dependent Tab, you can create new validity intervals for asset parameters (cost center, location, depreciation terms, useful life, etc.).

 For example:

   Interval 01.04.2022 – 31.03.2024 → Useful life = 5 years (original).

   Interval 01.04.2025 → Useful life = 10 years (changed).

This means you can split useful life by validity periods.

 🔹 2. What SAP Does with This

 SAP will recalculate depreciation prospectively only.

 It will not retroactively adjust past posted depreciation, even though you maintain intervals.

 In your case:

   It will still depreciate the NBV (24k) over the remaining 7 years (\~3.34k/year).

   It will not go back and restate the first 3 years at \$6k each.

🔹 3. What You Need for Your Requirement

Since you want the system to behave as if the asset was always 10 years from the start, you need two steps:

  1. Maintain new interval in AS02

    Go to AS02 → Time-Dependent → Create new validity starting FY25.

    Enter new useful life (10 years).

    This ensures the system spreads depreciation prospectively.

  1. Adjustment Posting

    Post the over-depreciated portion (\$18k) as a write-up (ABAAL) in FY25.

    After that, system will continue with the new planned depreciation (\$6k/year).

🔹 4. Alternative (Advanced)

Some companies handle this by:

 Creating a parallel depreciation area with the corrected useful life (10 years from beginning).

 The delta (–18k) between the main area and adjustment area can then be picked up and posted as a correction.

 

✅ Answer to your direct question:

Yes, you can add a new interval for useful life in the asset master data.

❌ But this alone will not generate the retroactive \$18k adjustment — you must post that separately.

entry.title: Re: Custom field in SAP EWM Public cloud
entry.content:
Hi Debojit,

 

1. First Requirement: We need a supplier information to be captured into EWM Public Cloud, for example Truck number, number of trucks for inbound, Mode of carrier, etc. in a custom field, from S4 Inbound Delivery to EWM system.

->You can create customized field with Business context "LE_SHP_DELIVERY", set the Business Scenario "Delivery Header to Warehouse Request Header" at APP Custom Fields.

 

2.2nd Requirement: I want to add a Material Group under "Stock & Bin" Node under "Physical/Available Stock" in Warehouse Monitor

->It is not possible to add Material group at APP Warehouse monitor or APP Manage Physical Stock, if the requirement is important for your client then you may consider Develop a customized Application with CDS view or ODATA APIs, listed the API link as below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c46da892efa14cea8347e9b872199d6f/b05c37a10150450fbff230adcfd8213e.html?version=LATEST&locale=en-US

 

Best Regards,

entry.title: Advanced Early Order Enrichment in SAP Order Management Foundation
entry.content:
You’re implementing SAP Order Management Foundation (OMF), a powerful engine for your order lifecycle. But what happens when standard processing isn't enough? Since OMF is a public cloud solution, extensibility options are limited by design. Your business needs to run a complex fraud check, pull in rich product data from a PIM, or verify export compliance before an order gets triggered for fulfillment. How do you inject this critical, custom logic without breaking the standard OMF processing flow?

The answer isn't a complex, high-risk custom development project. It’s a clever and elegant use of the framework OMF gives you with the concepts of Flow and the "Order transfer Hold". 

Meet the "Early Order Enrichment Pattern" — a powerful technique to (shortly) pause, enhance, and then seamlessly resume order processing. Let's dive into how you can use it to build sophisticated, decoupled extensions that supercharge your OMF instance. 

The Challenge: Breaking Out of the Standard Processing Flow

SAP OMF is designed to orchestrate a streamlined, end-to-end process: order ingestion, sourcing, fulfillment, subsequent processing. But real-world commerce is messy. You might need to ask:

  • Is this high-value order fraudulent?
  • Does this order item have all the details and specs the fulfillment system needs?
  • Can we legally ship this product to the customer's location?

Trying to bolt this logic onto a live, moving process is risky. You could create race conditions, data integrity nightmares, or process orders that should have been stopped. You need a safe window to work your magic.

The Solution: Press Pause with the OMF Flow Framework and the Transfer On Hold Capability

As a prerequisite for the "Early Order Enrichment Pattern", you must enable the Transfer Hold (TOH) capability. The transfer hold delays the order orchestration process to provide a period during which orders can be changed or canceled. This capability is enabled through a setting in the market:

  • transferHoldEnabled, set this parameter to true to enable the capability. Please note, that if this parameter is set to false, there is no way to enable the holding period for individual orders.
  • transferHoldDuration, this parameter controls in minutes the default holding period of an order that is created. Please note, that you should set a period, that is long enough to prevent unwanted continuation. The holding period can actively be ended via API call, so there is no need to set a "short and aggressive" holding period. We would rather recommend to set a longer period.

The process management component of this pattern is the OMF Flow Framework. This standard tool, configured via the Manage Flows app, is your command center. Every Flow is built on three simple concepts:

  • Triggers: An event that kicks off a process (like a new order).
  • Actions: The work to be done (like calling an API or updating a field).
  • Controls: The "if/then" logic that directs the traffic.

The "Early Order Enrichment Pattern" orchestrates these components with a simple, brilliant move: as soon as an order is created, we put it On Hold. The rest of the magic is the managed by listening and raising system events and custom order activities.

Why is this so powerful? An "On Hold" status acts as a protective shield. It stops the order from proceeding to standard fulfillment, giving you a controlled, isolated time window to perform any and all custom logic without interference. Events let you then control the reaction and the next activity.

How It Works: A Chain of Command for Your Data

With the order safely paused, we trigger a cascade of enrichment steps. Think of it as a relay race where each runner passes the baton to the next.

Here’s the play-by-play:

1. The Starting Gun & The First Check (e.g., Fraud Detection)

  • Trigger: The race begins when a new order is created.
  • Action: Call for Backup. The flow triggers the NEEDS_FRAUD_CHECK activity by calling your external fraud detection service via either an OMF Workflow or an SAP Integration Suite iFlow.
  • Action: Pass the Baton. The fraud score comes back. The flow updates the order and changes the Activity to READY_FOR_PIM_ENRICHMENT. The first leg of the race is done.

2. The Relay Continues (e.g., Product Enrichment)

  • Trigger: The READY_FOR_PIM_ENRICHMENT activity is the signal for the next runner.
  • Action: Get the Details. This new flow calls your PIM system, pulling in rich product descriptions, images, or technical specs.
  • Action: Pass the Baton (Again). The flow injects this new data into the order items and sets the next Activity, like ENRICHMENT_COMPLETE

3. Make sure the runner still holds the baton (e.g., Check result of previous step)

  • Trigger: The SAP_ORDERCHANGED_PREFULFILLMENT activity is the signal for the next runner.
  • Action: Check the status of the update. Since patching an order as an asynchronous API, you should check whether the order has been correctly updated by checking the status of the update or even check the enriched content.
  • Action: Pass the Baton (Again). The flow sets then the next Activity, like ENRICHMENT_COMPLETE

You can chain as many of these steps as you need—compliance checks, license verification, custom calculations—each one a clean, self-contained flow triggered by the previous one's activity.

4. The Finish Line: Release the Order

  • Trigger: The final activity, ENRICHMENT_COMPLETE, is set.
  • Action: Go, Go, Go! The final flow in our chain performs one last, critical action: it ends the "TOH" status.
  • Result: The shield is lowered. The order—now fully enriched, validated, and ready—is released back into the standard OMF process for fulfillment, smarter and safer than before.

Why You’ll Love This Pattern

This isn't just a workaround; it's a superior architectural choice.

  • Bulletproof Control: The "TOH" status guarantees that incomplete or unverified orders never accidentally slip through to fulfillment.
  • Ultimate Flexibility: Is your business adding a new compliance check next year? Just build a new flow and insert it into the chain. No need to touch your existing logic.
  • Clear Visibility: Each step is a distinct flow that can be monitored in the Manage Flows app. Troubleshooting becomes a breeze.
  • Decoupled & Clean: Your custom logic (iFlows, microservices) lives outside OMF. This allows specialized teams to work independently and keeps your OMF core pristine.

By mastering the "Early Order Enrichment Pattern," you transform SAP OMF from a standard processor into a dynamic, intelligent, and extensible platform ready for any business challenge you throw at it.

Conceptual Diagram

This swim lane illustrates various process steps and indicates their locations. While the OMF flow framework is depicted as a separate lane, it's integrated within the OMF solution to clarify the sequence of events.

OMF oversees the order, the flow framework handles all enhancement steps, the technical connections are managed by the Integration suite, and the specific logic and data, being independent, can be hosted anywhere.

 

Practical Use Cases

The usecases of this pattern are endless. Here are a few examples to spark your inspiration:

  • Advanced Fraud Detection: Call an external, specialized fraud detection service with order and customer details. Place the order on permanent hold if fraud is detected.
  • Product Data Enrichment: For items with only a SKU, call a Product Information Management (PIM) system to pull in full descriptions, technical specifications, images, or compliance data required by the fulfillment system.
  • License and Compliance Checks: For software or regulated goods, call an external service to verify licenses or check export/import compliance before releasing the order for fulfillment.

Benefits of this Approach

  • Flexibility & Extensibility: Add any number of complex business rules without modifying the OMF core application.
  • Decoupled Architecture: The custom logic (iFlows, microservices) is developed and maintained separately from OMF, allowing for independent updates and specialized teams.
  • Leverages Standard Features: This pattern uses the intended OMF Flow framework, ensuring stability and compatibility with future OMF upgrades.
  • Controlled & Failsafe Processing: The "TOH" status guarantees that incomplete or unverified orders are not processed, preventing data integrity issues downstream.
  • Transparency & Monitoring: Each step in the cascade can be monitored through the Manage Flows app, providing clear visibility into the enrichment process. In addition, you check your Cloud ALM instance for issues raised by the OMF application. You will find details there on failed updates, creations or any other issue that needs attention. Cloud ALM offers also ways to trigger automated notifications to decrease monitoring efforts and speed up the healing of issues.

entry.title: Re: SAC to ECC Data Retraction
entry.content:
I don't believe it would help in your situation given your exact landscape, so not offering as an 'answer'.

However, we are doing this for our SAC Planning solution. We have SAP BW/4HANA on-prem, ECC6.0 on-prem and also SAP Data Services. We have users do planning in SAC. Once the planning cycle is complete, we have built an interactive story that allows them to define a scope and then click a button to trigger the retraction to ECC.

What actually happens is:

  • The button calls an OData service technical object in the story.
  • The OData service is built in SAP BW and is established to accept parameters and trigger a process chain.
  • The Process Chain invokes a Data Services job to call the Data Export API and push the data into an established ADSO in BW.
  • Once the Data Services job is complete, the process chain has a custom program step that calls an established RFC enabled function module in ECC to deliver the data.
  • The function module in ECC loads the data to FICO PCA.

The OData service that SAC is calling in BW also has a method that returns a status, so SAC is able to poll that method to report the status back to the user in SAC.

Some of this might sound over-engineered, but it is done to leverage existing design patterns, and for various reasons, such as the fact we want the data in BW as well as PCA in ERP.

Cheers, Ivan.

entry.title: Re: Make To Stock MRP set up for each sales order require...
entry.content:
Hello @Mahendra_Kalal 

Your case is explained in the note 550568 - FAQ: Planning run (MD01, MD02, MD03, MDBT,...), question 6:

There are several requirements on one day. Is it possible that the MRP creates a separate procurement proposal for every requirement?

Same as for the daily lot size with a number of periods = 1 (lot size TB), requirements of one day are also grouped into one procurement proposal for the lot-for-lot order quantity (lot size EX) (see documentation for the lot-for-lot order quantity). Separate procurement proposals can be achieved only if you work with make-to-order production. Here, the requirements are managed in separate planning segments of the stock/requirements list.

You should switch to MTO if you need seperate planned orders, clearly assigned to sales orders.

@Lakshmipathi proposal of lot procedure FX and lot size = 1 is a nice workaround if your sales orders are for small quantities. Otherwise you'll end up with a lot of planned orders per single sales order.

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski

entry.title: AI-Assisted Smart Notes in Manage Project Billing
entry.content:
Hello All,

I am writing this article to give some insights on generative AI assistance features embedded in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud products like Professional Services.

Overview

The Smart Notes feature in the Manage Project Billing app proposes grammatically correct notes for project billing request items that already have notes maintained. Billing specialists need to manually review the maintained notes in the Note field in the Prepare Billing page of the Manage Project Billing app. This process can be very time-consuming because of the high volume of postings.

What's New

With the introduction of the new Smart Notes feature, you can get grammatically correct note proposals for project billing request items. When you accept the proposed notes, the updated notes are available immediately, thereby making the process more efficient.

How to access the feature

To access the Smart Notes feature, your business user needs to have the following authorizations assigned in the business role by an Administrator:

  • Business catalog: Project Billing — Smart Notes Feature (SAP_PS_BC_BILLG_AI_SNOTE_PC)

  • IAM app: Project Billing Request (Object Page) (F4456_SNOTE_TRAN)

  • To access this generative AI feature within SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, an additional entitlement and authorization may be required.

More information can be found here -->https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/ee9ee0ca4c3942068ea584d2f929b5b1/99bb1ef3b5ce46c08e64fcfdc6d3882f.html?state=TEST&version=2508.00

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Professional Services SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 

Thanks

Shubham

entry.title: How to Identify POs at 1st Tag Release (Status 03) in S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

We’re building a custom report in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to display POs that are either:

At the 1st tag (first-level release) Or fully released

Using CDS views, we can filter POs with status 05 (fully released). However, POs at 1st tag release still show as status 03 (not released), along with unreleased or held POs.

Question:
Is there any standard field, CDS view, or method to identify POs that have been approved at the 1st release step?

Thanks in advance for your help!

 

Regards,

entry.title: Hi What is the difference between document routing notification and document step exit reminder
entry.content:
Hi Team, 

In the route map we are using for performance form, there are 3 modification steps, and 2 signature steps, and final completion stage. Please help us with the following questions:

1. There are 2 email notification templates: Document Routing Notification , Document Routing Step Exit Notification - which seems to be triggered when routed to the same steps, on same conditions.

Ex: When an employee sends the form to next step, for a manager, will the Document Routing Step Exit Notification trigger to both employee and manager, and Document Routing Notification only for manager?

2. When the 2 modify steps owner is same and is single role, will  Document Routing Notification , Document Routing Step Exit Notification both trigger? (will employee get Document Routing Step Exit Notification too)

3. Will Document Routing Notification. Document Routing Step Exit Notification - trigger even in Signature steps?

4. Will Step Due Notification, Step Over Due Notification triggers for Completion stage as well?

Please help with the best practices usage of email notification in PM form. Thanks.

#performance #performanceform#routemap

# emailnotifications #bestpractices

entry.title: Re: Currency Conversion Project ECC6
entry.content:
Hi @praveen_143 

Thank you for your question. 

For your SAP ECC 6 currency conversion project, here is a concise summary of key activities for the FI and CO modules:

For the FI Module, you need to prepare and convert master data and open items, configure exchange rates, set up reference currencies, perform foreign currency valuation, and conduct thorough testing of financial statements.

For the CO Module, you are required to update cost center and internal order currency fields, adjust profitability analysis settings, update activity type prices, and validate cost allocations and other CO transactions after conversion.

In the general, you must complete pre-conversion checks, follow SAP-recommended procedures, back up your data, and update reporting formats post-conversion.

Please refer to the following official SAP documentation:

FI Configuration

FI Financial Accounting SAP ERP Central Component Release 6.0

Currency Conversion

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Newly implementing GRC 12 - Best way to on-board Mana...
entry.content:
Hi @twister091 

Thank you for the question.

For your SAP GRC 12 implementation with LDAP integration, the recommended approach to automatically assign managers during access request submission is as follows:

You need to configure agent determination rules in MSMP workflow to fetch manager information directly from LDAP using the manager attribute.

Then you should make use of BRF+ agent rules to dynamically assign the responsible manager for each request as it is submitted, so pre-creation of manager records is not necessary.

These official SAP documents for setup steps will guide you through.

GRC Access Control 12.0 Administrator Guide

I hope this provides the required guidance. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Use GitLab + Terraform for managing your SAP BTP and Cloud Foundry environments
entry.content:
This blog post is inspired by this brilliant blog post and this dev.to article.

Instead of GitHub we will be using GitLab as our CI/CD platform of choice 🚀 There are some minor differences though in the process when we compare the setup with GitHub which I want to point out. I will also provide you with a ready to use GitLab CI/CD pipeline and that you can use. In addition I'll explain our idea how we want to manage our BTP environment based on our experience managing google cloud by following basic security best practices like always following the principle of least privilege for each user.

How does it work?

Here is a brief explanation of the GitLab CI/CD workflow using terraform.

  1. A GitLab CI/CD pipeline is triggered (e.g., by a git push or a manual action).
  2. The GitLab OIDC Provider generates a JWT token for the running pipeline job. This token is made available to the job as a predefined CI/CD variable, such as $OIDC_TOKEN.
  3. This JWT Bearer token is used by the SAP BTP & Cloud Foundry Terraform providers in the Terraform scripts for authentication
  4. The Terraform providers send this token to SAP BTP and Cloud Foundry (UAA). These platforms, configured to trust your SAP Cloud Identity Service tenant, forward the token to it for validation.
  5. The SAP Cloud Identity Service validates the JWT's signature against the public keys (JWKS) of your GitLab instance's OIDC provider.
  6. If the token is successfully validated (based on the Enriched Token Claims settings, a user is found), the Terraform providers are authenticated and with the "mapped" user all subsequent calls will be made with this users authorization.

1. Create a new GitLab project

Create a new blank GitLab Project. The relevant content will be added later

2. Setup GitLab as OIDC provider in your SAP Cloud Identity Service tenant

First we need to setup GitLab.com as OIDC identity providers in the SAP Cloud Identity Service tenant.

  1. Login to your CIS tenant as admin.
  2. Create a new user group for all your GitLab users e.g. Name: GitLab CI/CD
  3. Go to 'Identity Providers' → 'Corporate Identity Providers' → Click '+ Create'.
  4. Use gitlab.com as provider name, select OpenID Connect Compliant as provider type. Click create
  5. Click on OpenID Connect Configuration. The Discovery URL for gitlab.com is https://gitlab.com/.well-known/openid-configuration 
  6. Now we also need a valid client for the authentication. Such an application has to be created in gitlab itself.
  7. Login to gitlab. Open a group or project that you want to use for btp deployments. In the menu select Settings -> Applications.
  8. Create a new application, give it a speaking name e.g. SAP Cloud Identity Service tenant <yourTenantId>, as Callback use https://<your-tenant>.accounts.ondemand.com/oauth2/callback, and select openid as Scope.
  9. Store the client id and client secret somewhere safe if needed.
  10. Enter the client id and client secret in the OpenID Connect Configuration.
  11. Add openid as scope and then save the configuration.
  12. Configure the token to user mapping in section Enriched Token Claims.
    Depending on your setup you need to define how you want to "identify" your users. You can find a list of supported claims from GitLab here
    Example:
    Claim: NameId
    Value: ${project_id}-${environment}@gitlab.com
  13. Follow the additional steps of the blog (Configure 'Identity Federation' to Restrict the GitHub IdP to GitHub CI/CD Users Only, Step 1.4)

Now just like in the blog we create a new user that follows our Enriched Token Claims format e.g. <gitlabProjectId>-prod@gitlab.com. Assign the user to the GitLab CI/CD group etc.

3. Maintain newly created user in SAP BTP with appropriate role

With the current setup the authentication would already work with the btp and cf providers but are still lacking the appropriate authorization for the new user.

Depending on the level of access (Globalaccount vs Subaccount) you need to assign the user manually and assign the role you need.

HINT: For some operations on subaccount level you might still need specific roles on global account level e.g. for reading assigned service plans


4 Setup the CI/CD pipeline + terraform code

Now we finally come to the fun part 😅

Our basic folder structure looks like this:

├── .gitignore
├── .gitlab-ci.yml
├── README.md
└── terraform
    ├── modules
    │   ├── btp
    │   │   ├── main.tf
    │   │   ├── outputs.tf
    │   │   ├── variables.tf
    │   │   └── versions.tf
    │   └── cloud_foundry
    │       ├── main.tf
    │       ├── outputs.tf
    │       ├── variables.tf
    │       └── versions.tf
    └── prod
        ├── .terraform.lock.hcl
        ├── main.tf
        ├── variables.tf
        └── versions.tf

We have a terraform folder, which contains all our terraform code. Inside the terraform folder we have a modules folder. One for btp and another one for cloud foundry. All resources that should be deployed in the specific environment will be described there.

Open the Spoiler to see the code for the btp folder

Spoiler
btp folder
main.tf
data "btp_subaccount" "subaccount" {
  id = var.subaccount_id
}

resource "random_uuid" "uuid" {}

locals {
  subaccount_name      = "${var.subaccount_stage} ${data.btp_subaccount.subaccount.name}"
  subaccount_subdomain = join("-", [lower(replace("${var.subaccount_stage}-${data.btp_subaccount.subaccount.name}", " ", "-")), random_uuid.uuid.result])
}

resource "btp_subaccount_environment_instance" "cloudfoundry" {
  subaccount_id    = var.subaccount_id
  name             = "${data.btp_subaccount.subaccount.name} ${var.subaccount_stage}"
  environment_type = "cloudfoundry"
  service_name     = "cloudfoundry"
  plan_name        = "standard"

  parameters = jsonencode({
    instance_name = local.subaccount_subdomain
  })
}
​

variables.tf

variable "subaccount_id" {
  description = "The subaccount ID."
  type        = string
}

variable "subaccount_stage" {
  description = "The deployment stage for the subaccount."
  type        = string

  validation {
    condition     = contains(["dev", "qas", "prod"], var.subaccount_stage)
    error_message = "The stage must be dev, qas or prod."
  }
}

outputs.tf


output "cf_api_url" {
  value       = jsondecode(btp_subaccount_environment_instance.cloudfoundry.labels)["API Endpoint"]
  description = "The Cloud Foundry API URL"
}

output "cf_org_id" {
  value       = jsondecode(btp_subaccount_environment_instance.cloudfoundry.labels)["Org ID"]
  description = "The Cloud Foundry organization ID"
}

versions.tf

terraform {
  required_version = ">= 1.10.0"
  required_providers {
    btp = {
      source  = "SAP/btp"
      version = "~>1.15.1"
    }
  }
}

Open the Spoiler to see the code for the cloud foundry folder

 

Spoiler
variables.tf
variable "cf_org_id" {
  description = "The Cloud Foundry organization ID"
  type        = string
}

variable "subaccount_stage" {
  description = "The deployment stage for the subaccount."
  type        = string

  validation {
    condition     = contains(["dev", "qas", "prod"], var.subaccount_stage)
    error_message = "The stage must be dev, qas or prod."
  }
}
​

main.tf

Spoiler
resource "cloudfoundry_space" "space" {
name = var.subaccount_stage
org = var.cf_org_id
}

data "cloudfoundry_service_plan" "html5_apps_repo_plan_cf" {
service_offering_name = "html5-apps-repo"
name = "app-host"
}

resource "cloudfoundry_service_instance" "html5_repo" {
name = "html5-repo-${var.subaccount_stage}"
space = cloudfoundry_space.space.id
service_plan = data.cloudfoundry_service_plan.html5_apps_repo_plan_cf.id
type = "managed"
}
outputs.tf is empty
versions.tf
terraform {
  required_providers {
    cloudfoundry = {
      source  = "cloudfoundry/cloudfoundry"
      version = "1.8.0"
    }
  }
}
​

And here is the code that will be accessed from our ci/cd pipeline. Many projects of us have different environments/stages (dev/qas/prod). There for we manage the main code in modules with all the ressources that will be deployed in each environment.

The environment/stages folders (dev,qas,prod) then basically just use the defined modules with some variables. This ensures that each environment contains the same resources (or differ a little bit depending on requirements e.g. a prod database setup might be different compared to dev/qas database setup).

Open the Spoiler to see the code for the prod folder.

 

Spoiler
variables.tf (all variable values are defined in the GitLab UI)
variable "globalaccount" {
  description = "The name of the global account in SAP BTP."
  type        = string
}

variable "subaccount_id" {
  description = "The subaccount ID."
  type        = string
}

variable "idp_origin_key" {
  description = "The origin key for the Identity Provider (IDP)."
  type        = string
}
variable "cf_region" {
  description = "The region for the Cloud Foundry environment."
  type        = string
}

variable "subaccount_stage" {
  description = "The deployment stage for the subaccount."
  type        = string

  validation {
    condition     = contains(["dev", "qas", "prod"], var.subaccount_stage)
    error_message = "The stage must be dev, qas or prod."
  }
}
​

providers.tf

provider "btp" {
  globalaccount = var.globalaccount
  idp           = var.idp_origin_key
}

provider "cloudfoundry" {
  api_url = "https://api.cf.${var.cf_region}.hana.ondemand.com"
  origin  = var.idp_origin_key
}

versions.tf (backend "http" {} is enough to manage the terraform state in GitLab)

terraform {
  required_version = ">= 1.10.0"
  required_providers {
    btp = {
      source  = "SAP/btp"
      version = "~>1.15.1"
    }
    cloudfoundry = {
      source  = "cloudfoundry/cloudfoundry"
      version = "1.8.0"
    }
  }
  backend "http" {}
}
main.tf
module "btp" {
  source           = "../modules/btp"
  subaccount_id    = var.subaccount_id
  subaccount_stage = var.subaccount_stage
}

module "cloud_foundry" {
  source           = "../modules/cloud_foundry"
  cf_org_id        = module.btp.cf_org_id
  subaccount_stage = var.subaccount_stage
}
​

 

 

 

4.1 GitLab CI/CD Pipeline

This is where the 🪄 magic happens. Let's have a look at the pipeline definition ( .gitlab-ci.yml file ).

Hint: In our environment we use GitLab CI/CD components. This avoids copy and pasting pipeline definitions and allows central maintenance including versioning and testing.

variables:
    TF_ROOT: $CI_PROJECT_DIR/terraform/$CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME
    TF_STATE_NAME: $CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME
    TF_VERSION: "1.12.2"

stages:
    - terraform prepare
    - terraform check
    - terraform plan
    - terraform apply

.job_template:
    image:
        name: hashicorp/terraform:$TF_VERSION
        entrypoint: [""]
    before_script:
        - cd $TF_ROOT
    variables:
        TF_HTTP_ADDRESS: "${CI_API_V4_URL}/projects/${CI_PROJECT_ID}/terraform/state/${TF_STATE_NAME}"
        TF_HTTP_LOCK_ADDRESS: "${TF_HTTP_ADDRESS}/lock"
        TF_HTTP_UNLOCK_ADDRESS: "${TF_HTTP_ADDRESS}/lock"
        TF_HTTP_LOCK_METHOD: "POST"
        TF_HTTP_UNLOCK_METHOD: "DELETE"
        TF_HTTP_RETRY_WAIT_MIN: "5"
        TF_HTTP_USERNAME: "gitlab-ci-token"
        TF_HTTP_PASSWORD: ${CI_JOB_TOKEN}
        TF_IN_AUTOMATION: "true"
    cache:
        key: "$CI_PROJECT_ID-$CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME-$CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME"
        paths:
            - "$TF_ROOT/.terraform"
        policy: pull
    id_tokens:
        OIDC_TOKEN:
            aud: $CIS_TENANT_URL

"terraform prepare":
    stage: terraform prepare
    extends: .job_template
    environment:
        action: prepare
        name: prod
    cache:
        policy: push
    script:
        - terraform init
        - terraform validate
    resource_group: state-$CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME

"terraform tf lint":
    stage: terraform prepare
    extends: .job_template
    image:
        name: ghcr.io/terraform-linters/tflint:v0.58.1
    environment:
        action: prepare
        name: prod
    script:
        - tflint --init
        - tflint --recursive

"terraform tf fmt":
    stage: terraform prepare
    extends: .job_template
    environment:
        action: prepare
        name: prod
    script:
        - terraform fmt -recursive -check

"terraform plan":
    stage: terraform plan
    extends: .job_template
    variables:
        BTP_ASSERTION: $OIDC_TOKEN
        CF_ASSERTION_TOKEN: $OIDC_TOKEN
    environment:
        action: prepare
        name: prod
    script:
        - terraform init
        - terraform plan -input=false -out="plan.cache"
        - apk --no-cache add jq
        - terraform show -json "plan.cache" | jq -r "( [.resource_changes[]?.change.actions?] | flatten) | { \"create\":(map(select(.==\"create\")) | length), \"update\":(map(select(.==\"update\")) | length), \"delete\":(map(select(.==\"delete\")) | length) }" > plan.json
    artifacts:
        name: plan
        paths:
            - "$TF_ROOT/plan.cache"
        reports:
            terraform:
                - "$TF_ROOT/plan.json"
    needs:
        - "terraform prepare"
    resource_group: state-$CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME

"terraform apply":
    stage: terraform apply
    extends: .job_template
    variables:
        BTP_ASSERTION: $OIDC_TOKEN
        CF_ASSERTION_TOKEN: $OIDC_TOKEN
    environment:
        action: start
        name: prod
    script:
        - terraform init
        - terraform apply -input=false "plan.cache"
    rules:
        - if: "$CI_COMMIT_BRANCH == $CI_DEFAULT_BRANCH"
          when: manual
    needs:
        - "terraform plan"
    resource_group: state-$CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME
    when: manual
    allow_failure: false

If you feel overwhelmed, that's ok 😅 I try to explain the most important parts.

We are using the official terraform image therefore we have to do some standard customization in the .job_template by setting some terraform variables for managing the state hosted on GitLab.

But most important is the definition of our token:

    id_tokens:
        OIDC_TOKEN:
            aud: $CIS_TENANT_URL

The variable $OIDC_TOKEN is a predefined, short-lived JWT token that GitLab automatically generates for authenticating with OIDC providers. This is a secure method that avoids storing static secrets. In order to use it with our Cloud Identity Service we need to adjust the aud property (audience) and use the URL of our Cloud Identity Service Tenant.

Now all we need to take care of assigning the value of the OIDC_TOKEN to the environment variables needed by the btp and cloud foundry terraform providers. We do this on the job level and assign the value of the OIDC token to the environment variables read by the terraform providers:

    variables:
        BTP_ASSERTION: $OIDC_TOKEN
        CF_ASSERTION_TOKEN: $OIDC_TOKEN

4.3 Terraform provider setup

Now we "only" need to setup the terraform providers for btp and cloud foundry to ensure that they use the JWT token for authentication. This is done in terraform/prod/providers.tf

provider "btp" {
  globalaccount = var.globalaccount
  idp           = var.idp_origin_key
}

provider "cloudfoundry" {
  api_url = "https://api.cf.${var.cf_region}.hana.ondemand.com"
  origin  = var.idp_origin_key
}

4.4 Define Terraform Variables for prod environment in GitLab

The last step is to maintain the needed variables for the prod environment in GitLab.

Open your project on GitLab and go to Settings -> CI/CD -> Variables

Now you can maintain all needed terraform variables. Important if to always prefix them with TF_VAR_variable_name.

By making use of the environment and managing the main resources inside modules, are able to deploy all needed environments/stages per project by using just one GitLab project 🚀.

This is the complete setup. Feel free to use it, adjust it, improve it, ... . I hope you learned something today and can benefit from the approach I am demonstrating here.

Outlook to our future approach

We want to follow our design principle that we have already successfully deployed in Google Cloud:

  • One central landing zone project which contains the overall global btp landscape and manages global trust, directories and subaccounts
    • The subaccount module will not only create the subaccount but also the "technical user" needed for the GitLab integration by utilizing the SAP Cloud Identity Provider Terraform Provider and assign this user to the appropriate role
    • In google cloud the creator of the project (=subaccount in btp), automatically became the owner of the project (full access). At the end of the project creation we always removed the landscaper user from the owner role to ensure that only the newly created project technical user is able to deploy ressources inside the project.
      We will try to setup the same approach in BTP. The landscape user should not be able to create any additional ressources inside a subaccount after the subaccount setup. This is the responsibility of the team working on the new project inside the subaccount.
  • Almost all platform users will only have viewer access to ensure that nobody does any changes by "accident". The terraform workflow sometimes takes a little longer compared to just a few clicks, but IaC brings you all the benefits compared to ClickOps
  • Every new BTP project will have one GitLab project for maintaining the infrastructure but also everything else needed for the project.
    • Right now we are migrating a CAP app from Google Cloud to SAP BTP (forced by the new license 🙄)
    • The terraform code and the CAP source code are all managed in the same GitLab Project. One team member can take of provisioning the infrastructure, while another team member is adapting the CAP code. CAP app deployment will then also be done using the GitLab CI/CD pipeline (and of course automated tests upfront to ensure we did not break anything).

Questions?

Feel free to leave a comment or contact me directly here or via LinkedIn.

entry.title: Re: Working with RAP BO Events end-to-end - Event-driven-architecture - Event framework
entry.content:
Hi @vmolina 

You are correct that RAP BOs (the R_ ones) are often not released. Instead, the RAP BO Interface (I_) is released. Taking the sales order as example, R_SalesOrderTP has the events but isn't released with a C1 contract. Looking at the BO interface, I_SalesOrderTP, it is released, but, the events aren't on the interface. Now the interface is meant as stable interaction with the BO, and that's why this is the one that gets released.

So what now, as you asked? You can still do this and make it work via clean core Tier 2 (wrapper) or, now with the new clean core concept introduced on Aug 12 2025, this would be level B. Let's look at it.

You start by creating your custom payload (notice that payloads need to be flat for derived events). For my sales order example I created ZP_SalesOrder_EventExt. This one can be saved as ABAP Cloud, meaning level A (Tier 1).

define root view entity ZP_SalesOrder_EventExt as select from I_SalesOrder
{
  key SalesOrder,
  @Event.context.attribute: 'xsapordtype'
  SalesOrderType,
  @Event.context.attribute: 'xsapslsorg'
  SalesOrganization,
  DistributionChannel,
  OrganizationDivision,
  SoldToParty,
  CustomerGroup,
  ShippingCondition,
  IncotermsClassification,
  OverallSDProcessStatus
}

(above you also have examples on how to create custom even filters, as mentioned in my blog)

After this, now you can create your event extension. Right-click the RAP BO's behavior definition (R_SalesOrderTP for me) and choose new behavior extension. Then here you simply derive your event:

extension
//using interface i_salesordertp
;
extend behavior for SalesOrder {
  managed event ZChangedExtended on Changed parameter ZP_SalesOrder_EventExt;
}

Now ideally, you would have line 2 above active, as then you are using the interface I_SalesOrderTP. But, as already established, the interface does not have the events. So we leave that line away and then we can activate this. This extension CDS is your wrapper, so it needs to be saved as Standard ABAP, as it accesses R_SalesOrderTP which is not released.

Lastly if you want to expose this via your channel to Event Mesh, you need to create the event binding (Business Service - Event Binding) for the new event, in my case that's ZChangedExtended as written above.

And that's it. Not exactly a workaround, but what needs to be done while the events are not exposed on the interface. But always try to achieve your extensions or custom code by using the RAP BO interface.

BR, Melanie

entry.title: Re: Referencing New Entity in Batch Request
entry.content:
Hello @Kaito2 

Thank you for your question

In a batch changeset, the Content-ID alias ($1) cannot be used with a path segment like $1/SAP__self.PostToAccounting — this is why you saw “Content ID '$1' is not valid”.

The supported solution is to call the unbound action PostToAccounting and pass the new Billing Document reference in the request body, for example:

POST BillingDocument/PostToAccounting

{ "BillingDocument": "$1" }

Both requests remain within the same changeset; therefore, if posting to accounting fails, the billing document will not be generated.

Let me know if it works

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Change Mail Attachment Name for Billing Document
entry.content: There is a BAdI APOC_SET_OUTPUT_DOCUMENT_NAME to set the name of the rendered documents (forms) during output. It overwrites the document name that is provided by the SAP business application.

entry.title: Switching Cloud Identity tenant in Subaccount Trust Configuration
entry.content:
With OIDC Trusts in a Subaccount to Cloud Identity Services it's possible to switch the Cloud Identity tenant. You can simply edit the config and switch the tenant. User IDs and Authorizations remain untouched - everything works fine.

In the "old" Cloud Identity Tenant it even removes the Application and moves it to the "new" tenant.

Has anyone else used this in a production environment? Is this an official feature that's supported by SAP?

Regards

BTW here is how you can switch a Cloud Identity trust from SAML to OIDC:

entry.title: Re: Manage Withholding Tax Items Peru – Issue with Report...
entry.content:
Hello @LuisaFernanda0204 

Hi Luisa,

I have checked your screenshots; the behaviour you're seeing is in line with the intended design. of the Peru “Manage Withholding Tax Items” app in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition.

Understanding why this occurs

The app does not transfer the invoice to a different tax period..

The Exclude, Hold, and Include functions solely determine whether an item appears in the withholding tax report run.

When you select August as the Reporting Date, the system continues to evaluate the original posting date in July. This is why the invoice does not show up in August, but appears in July with either 202508 (matching the period of the reporting date) or 999912 (a placeholder for held items).

Key points

 Exclude → Removes the item from the reporting run completely.

Hold → Keeps the item but marks it with tax period 999912, a technical placeholder; the item is on hold and won’t be reported in the regular period.

Include → The item remains with the original posting period logic. It does not move the invoice to a new period, like August.

Limitation

  •  The app cannot change tax periods retroactively. According to Peru's legal framework, the invoice must stay in its original period based on the posting or withholding tax date.  
  • SAP's delivered functionality is designed to flag items excluded, hold, and include, but does not change their reporting periods.

Here's what you can do to make a difference.

  • If the invoice genuinely relates to a later period, the correction is usually achieved by posting a reversal or rebooking and re-issuing the withholding tax.
  • Alternatively, you can handle the exception manually in your statutory return, since the system will not “move” it from July to August.

References

  • SAP Help – Withholding Tax Reporting for Peru
  • 3381726 - Modifying the admin user - SAP Commerce

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: I can't to assign a recipient name to a namespace "/M...
entry.content:
Hi @0uTY 

Thank you for your qeustion.

To resolve the issue with assigning recipients using namespace /MMIM in S/4HANA Public Cloud, I suggest you follow the following steps:

First, you need to verify recipients are correctly configured for your communication scenario via the Assign Recipients to Users app.

Then ensure scope items needed for Business Network integration are activated. Missing scenarios can prevent assignment.

Thereafter check that your users have required roles and business catalogs, you can refer to SAP Note 3096609 for authorization details.

Finally, reload or sync your system configurations after changes.

If it is still unresolved, contact SAP Support with cloud version details and reference the relevant SAP documentation.

I hope this provides some insights. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.content:
The way the sunset process works, is that we will create a new read-only "Archived Content" area of the Community that we will move the entire group and its content to. This means that all the content of the inactive groups will still remain in the public community, and can be found both by search and by navigation. Sunsetting groups will therefore also not affect any community member's reputation, as all content you have published to any of the sunset groups will remain in your profile.

entry.title: Re: SAP SF LMS Assign security domains automatically to u...
entry.content:
Hi Olga,

We are facing the same issue at a client currently. We're going to put a custom field on the Employee Profile, dedicated to LMS domains, and map it to the domain field in System Configuration > Connectors on the sfuser.field.mapping.data.DMN_ID mapping property. 

You could also use an existing field (like country or legal entity) if that matches your domain structure. Just Make sure the field on EP holds the same values as the domains in your LMS, because if the domain ID doe not exist in LMS, the connector will create them automatically themselves. If the field is empty, the users should end up in the configured default domain.

Not tested yet in practice, but we believe this should work.

entry.title: Re: Two PR items triggered from external operation in maintenance order
entry.content:
Hello,

Not sure if you found an answer to this, but i will tell you my solution.

When using a control key with external processing (e.g., YBM2 with External Operation flag active), SAP automatically generates a PR item for the operation itself, even if service lines (item category D) are already defined under the Services tab. So, you end up with:

- One PR item from the external operation itself (which is empty if no value is maintained).

- One PR item from the service line (item category D) — which contains your actual service data.

You need to adjust the control key configuration to avoid PR generation from the operation line:  “Define Control Key” -> Control key: YBM2 -> Deselect the Following Flags: External Processing → Uncheck this; Automatically generate PR (if available) uncheck this.

You can test it and see if it works for you 🙂

Best regards,

Luisa

entry.title: Building an AI-Powered Assistant with SAP AI Core and SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

In today’s rapidly evolving digital landscape, AI-powered assistants have emerged as indispensable assets for businesses aiming to elevate customer service, increase productivity, and optimize operations. This comprehensive guide will walk you through the process of building a sophisticated AI assistant using SAP AI Core and SAP Build Apps—a powerful, no-code combination that empowers users to harness enterprise-grade AI capabilities without the need for traditional programming expertise.

Architecture Overview

  1. SAP Build Apps: Serves as the front-end development platform for crafting intuitive user interfaces
  2. SAP AI Core: Acts as the robust runtime engine that executes AI workloads and delivers foundation model capabilities
  3. BTP Destination: Functions as the middleware layer that securely connects Build Apps to AI Core, ensuring smooth and scalable integration.

The integration flow works as follows:

Users engage with the application through the intuitive SAP Build Apps interface. When an input is submitted, it is seamlessly transmitted via BTP Destinations to SAP AI Core, which orchestrates the request. AI Core then processes the input using the powerful GPT-4o model hosted on Azure OpenAI. Once the AI generates a response, the result is returned through the same secure channel and elegantly displayed within the Build Apps interface for the user.

Prerequisites

  1. SAP BTP account (free tier)
  2. Access to SAP AI Core with sap-internal or extended service plan
  3. SAP Build Apps subscription
  4. SAP AI Launchpad subscription

Step 1: Setting Up Your SAP BTP Environment

Enable Required Services or Applications

  1. Navigate to your SAP BTP Global Account
  2. Go to Instances and Subscriptions section
  3. Search for and enable these applications:
    • AI Launchpad
    • AI Core
    • Build Apps

Subscribe to SAP Build Apps 

Create AI Core Instance

  1. In your sub-account, go to Services > Instances and Subscriptions
  2. Create a new instance of AI Core
  3. Choose the extended or sap-internal service plan (required for foundation models)
  4. Create a service key for the AI Core instance - save this information as you'll need it later

Step 2: Configure SAP AI Launchpad

Create Connection to AI Core

  1. Open SAP AI Launchpad
  2. Navigate to the Connections section
  3. Create a new connection using the service key information from Step 1
  4. Create a workspace (you can use "default" as the name)

Set Up Foundation Models

  1. In AI Launchpad, go to ML Operations > Scenarios
  2. You should see Foundation Models - these are pre-configured scenarios provided by SAP.

Deploy the Model

  1. Go to Deployments and click Create
  2. Select your configuration
  3. Choose Standard duration (or custom if you prefer)
  4. Wait for the deployment status to show Running - this may take a few minutes

Step 3: Create BTP Destination

The destination acts as a bridge between Build Apps and AI Core.

  1. In BTP Cockpit, go to Connectivity > Destinations
  2. Click New Destination and configure like below in screenshot and add the additional properties as well:

Additional Properties:

HTML5.DynamicDestinationtrue
URL.headers.AI-Resource-Groupdefault
AppGyver.Enabledtrue
URL.headers.Content-Type application/json

Step 4: Build the Chatbot Interface with SAP Build Apps

Create New Project

  1. Open SAP Build Apps
  2. Click Create > Build an Application
  3. Choose Web & Mobile Application
  4. Name your project: Virtual Assistant

Design the User Interface

  1. Remove all the previous elements from the UI
  2. Add a Large Image List Item for displaying chat history
  3. Modify the list item:
  4. Add an Input Field for user messages (remove the label)
  5. Add a Button with label "Submit"

Create Variables

Create these variables to manage data flow:

  1. App Variable:
    • history (List of objects)
      • role (Text)
      • content (Text)

  1. Page Variable: input
    • Type: Text
    • Purpose: Capture user input

Step 5: Set Up Data Integration

Create Data Entity

  1. Go to Integrations tab
  2. Select SAP BTP Destination REST API integration
  3. Configure:
    • Name: ai-assistant-tool
    • Destination: Select your created destination (ai-destination)
    • Resource Schema: Create list of objects with role and content properties

Configure API Endpoint

  1. Enable the Create method (for POST requests)
  2. Set the relative URL: /inference/deployments/[DEPLOYMENT_ID]/chat/completions?api-version=2024-06-01 
    • Get the deployment ID from your AI Launchpad deployment URL

Test the Connection

Create Data Variable

  1. Create a Data Variable using your data entity
  2. This will handle the communication with AI Core

Step 6: Implement Chatbot Logic

Bind UI Components

  1. Bind List Component:
    • Select the Large Image List Item
    • Bind Repeat with to app variable: history
    • Bind Title to data item: role
    • Bind Description to data item: content
  2. Bind Input Field:
    • Bind Value to page variable: input

Add Button Logic

Create the following logic flow for the Send button:

Set App Variable ->  Create Record -> Set App Variable (for response) -> Set Page Variable:

Step 7: Testing Your Chatbot

Web Testing

  1. Use the Preview feature in Build Apps
  2. Test various scenarios

Mobile Testing

  1. Install the SAP Build Apps mobile app
  2. Scan the QR code from your project
  3. Test on both iOS and Android devices

 

Conclusion

You’ve now developed a sophisticated AI-powered assistant using SAP’s low-code/no-code platform — a clear demonstration of how SAP Build Apps intuitive interface design seamlessly integrates with the advanced AI capabilities of SAP AI Core.

The assistant you've created goes beyond a basic Q&A tool. It’s a flexible, scalable solution that can be tailored to a wide range of business scenarios. Whether your goal is to enhance customer service, streamline internal operations, or deliver personalized learning experiences, this solution provides a solid foundation for building intelligent, enterprise-ready applications.

entry.title: Re: Growth Rebate in Condition Contract
entry.content:
Hello Drahul,

The problem for Year over Year value growth can be solved by creating additional CDS view for previous year. You would need to add customizing here:

Settlement Management -> Condition Contract Management -> Condition Contract Settlement -> Define and Configure Profiles for Business Volume Determination.

You should maintain additional tables for previous year - there is an indicator for BV CDS Period where you can choose 'Previous year'. Afterwards, you need to transfer the value via Amount Fields.

To calculate the growth you need to anyway contact your ABAP developer, there are many approaches which can be used but I would go for either development of scale base routine or using point scale and creating logic to calculate growth in transfer manager.

One of the things you should take into consideration that condition for calculation should be an item condition because if you use point scale for the purpose.

entry.title: Re: SAP B1 10.0 - SBO Mailer stop working for Gmail (from...
entry.content:
Hi @AksharChem 

Thank you for your question.

To continue sending emails via Gmail using SBO Mailer, I suggest you consider doing the following:

First, enable 2-Factor Authentication and generate a Gmail app password for the mailer.

Then set up SMTP Relay service in Google Admin Console and configure SBO Mailer to use this relay with IP-based authentication.

Finally, check for future SBO Mailer updates that supports OAuth 2.0 or consider evaluating third-party mailers with OAuth support.

I hope this provides the desired insights. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to Identify POs at 1st Tag Release (Status 03) in...
entry.content:
Hi @PTiwari 

Thank you for your question. Let me walk you through it.

Standard PO status 03 only indicates not released, which includes POs in the first release step as well as fully held or unreleased POs.

Please note that there is no direct standard field or CDS view that distinctly flags POs at the first release stage.

I suggest you consider using the CDS view I_PurchaseOrderAPI01 and integrating workflow or release decision logs to determine your detailed approval statuses.

Make sure to utilize the Flexible Workflow Administrator app to monitor the release workflows and extract release step details.

It is important to note that custom reporting based on workflow tables may be required to meet precise reporting requirements.

See KBA 3556752 for more details.

I hope this provides the desired insights. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

SAP regularly updates and deprecates business catalogues. When a catalogue is deprecated, SAP provides guidance and successor catalogues directly in the system. To find the replacement for this catalogue, please use the Fiori app Manage Business Role

Changes After Upgrade. This app lists all deprecated business catalogues and shows their recommended replacements, ensuring your authorisation setup is always current. You can also download a CSV report or check the catalogue details for specific successor information.

entry.title: Re: Filtering in Advanced Event Mesh from IDOC
entry.content:
Hi @priya_sshekhar 

Thank you for your question.

AEM topic subscriptions filter based on topic names and wildcards but do not support filtering on payload attributes such as customer account groups directly. To enable you filter IDocs by account groups 0002 and 0003, you can implement filtering either:

In SAP CPI before publishing to AEM, or in the consumer application processing AEM messages.

Alternatively, publishing separate topics per customer account group at source can help you carry out topic-level filtering.

Please refer to SAP documentation for best practices.

Publish and Subscribe to Events

Topic Architecture Best Practices

 

I hope this provides the desired insights. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAPUI5 attachPropertyChange not working when extendin...
entry.content:
For me this also is confusing but you can easily make it work by using PropertyBinding.

...
const publicSearchModel = searchControl.getPublicSearchModel();
const selectionVisibilityBinding = new sap.ui.model.PropertyBinding(
publicSearchModel,
"/selectionVisibility",
publicSearchModel.getContext("/")
);
selectionVisibilityBinding.attachChange((oEvent) => {
...

Also see official documentation of model event 'propertyChange'.
https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/#/api/sap.ui.model.Model%23events/propertyChange
...
The propertyChange event is fired when changes occur to a property value in the model. The event contains a reason parameter which describes the cause of the property value change. Currently the event is only fired with reason sap.ui.model.ChangeReason.Binding which is fired when two way changes occur to a value of a property binding.
...

entry.title: Re: Serial Number in Storage Bin Location
entry.content:
Hello @Charisma_fitra 

Although you’re using the same Serial Number (SN) Profile for both products, the behaviour might vary depending on the existing stock levels and how SNs are managed in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

The error occurs because your old product already has stock without serial numbers, while the SN profile now requires every goods receipt to include them. SN management cannot be applied retroactively; existing stock remains non-SN, and any new GR must comply with the profile rules.

To resolve this, you need to either proceed with the options available.

Clear or transfer out the old non-SN stock and re-receipt it with serial numbers, or separate legacy stock from new SN-managed stock.

Let me know if you need more support

With regards

Chuma
